text: During endodontic treatment of a maxillary first molar, the clinician prepares the access cavity and negotiates the mesiobuccal canal. Which additional step is most critical for ensuring long-term success of treatment in this tooth?
option1: Ensuring patency of the distobuccal root canal
option2: Identifying and treating the MB2 canal in the mesiobuccal root
option3: Over-instrumenting the palatal canal to confirm working length
option4: Placing a post immediately in the palatal canal
explanation: Endodontic success in maxillary first molars depends on careful management of the mesiobuccal root, which often contains two canals. The MB2 canal is typically located palatal and slightly mesial to MB1 on the chamber floor, and may be very narrow or calcified. Failure to locate and instrument MB2 is one of the leading causes of endodontic failure in these teeth, as untreated tissue can harbor bacteria and cause persistent periapical disease. Magnification, enhanced illumination, and ultrasonic troughing are often used to find MB2. By contrast, the distobuccal and palatal roots almost always have a single canal and pose fewer anatomical challenges.

text: Which anterior tooth is most likely to contain two root canals?
explanation:
Among anterior teeth, mandibular incisors‚Äîespecially the mandibular lateral incisor‚Äîmost often present two canals within a single root (buccal and lingual). The lingual canal is easily missed without careful troughing, illumination, and angled radiographs. Maxillary incisors and canines are typically single canal; the mandibular canine is notable for a possible bifurcated root rather than canal multiplicity.
Typical Canal Counts ‚Äî Quick Scan
Tooth# Canals / Prevalence
Mandibular central incisor1C ‚âà 70% ¬∑ 2C ‚âà 30%
Mandibular lateral incisor1C ‚âà 56% ¬∑ 2C ‚âà 44%
High‚Äëyield review: mandibular lateral‚ÄîDL incisal twist; cingulum slightly distal; root with M/D concavities; incisal edge lingual to long axis; occludes with maxillary central and lateral.

text: Which anterior tooth is characterized by an incisal edge that appears twisted distolingually when viewed from the incisal aspect?
explanation: The mandibular lateral incisor resembles the central but is slightly larger and less symmetrical and shows a diagnostic distolingual twist of the incisal edge to conform to the mandibular arch. This twist is a decisive identification cue that also explains minor differences in contact and wear facets relative to the central incisor. High‚Äëyield review: MMR > DMR; cingulum slightly distal; root with deeper mesial concavity; occludes with maxillary central and lateral incisors.

text: Which anterior tooth may present with a bifurcated root (buccal and lingual), making it an exception to the single-root rule?
explanation: The mandibular canine is the only anterior tooth that may exhibit a bifurcated root (buccal and lingual). While most mandibular canines are single‚Äërooted with one canal, variations include two canals that may remain separate. Clinically, the long crown, oval root cross‚Äësection, and proximal concavities demand careful endodontic access and extraction planning. High‚Äëyield review: longest crown overall; cusp tip slightly lingual to long axis; mesial cusp ridge < distal; occludes with maxillary lateral incisor and first premolar.

text: Which permanent tooth has a distal marginal ridge that is more prominent than the mesial marginal ridge?
explanation: The mandibular first premolar uniquely has a distal marginal ridge more prominent than the mesial marginal ridge. Its morphology includes a dominant buccal cusp, a small often nonfunctional lingual cusp, a mesiolingual developmental groove that may cross the MMR, and a lingually inclined occlusal plane‚Äîfeatures that guide preparation outline and occlusal scheme. High‚Äëyield review: occlusal diamond; transverse ridge pronounced; root broader B‚ÄëL; occludes with maxillary canine and first premolar.

text: Which tooth is most commonly associated with a C-shaped root canal configuration?
explanation: The mandibular second molar is most commonly associated with a C‚Äëshaped canal configuration created by root fusion and interconnecting isthmuses. Debridement requires activated irrigation, careful scouting, and obturation techniques capable of filling fins and webs. High‚Äëyield review: second molar‚Äîrectangular occlusal table, +‚Äëlike groove pattern, roots closer and distally inclined; more frequent cervical enamel projections than first molar.

text: Which tooth may exhibit a C-shaped developmental groove on its crown?
explanation:
In the three‚Äëcusp (Y‚Äëtype) form of the mandibular second premolar, a C‚Äëshaped developmental groove may appear on the lingual between the mesiolingual and distolingual cusps, curving toward the central pit. It is the only premolar formed from five lobes (three buccal and two lingual); recognition of Y/H/U patterns aids identification, caries‚Äërisk assessment, and prep design.
Mandibular 2nd Premolar ‚Äî Occlusal Configurations
PatternCuspsKey features
Y-type (most common)3 (B, ML, DL)ML > DL; central pit; may show C-shaped groove lingually
H-type2 (B, L)Short central groove; ‚ÄúH‚Äù appearance
U-type2 (B, L)Crescent-shaped central groove; ‚ÄúU‚Äù appearance
High‚Äëyield review: Y‚Äëtype‚ÄîML > DL; central pit present; H‚Äëtype‚Äîshort central groove; U‚Äëtype‚Äîcrescent‚Äëshaped central groove; lingual HOC often in occlusal third.

text: Which premolar is most likely to have two roots, making it an exception among premolars?
explanation:
The maxillary first premolar frequently has two roots (buccal and palatal) and two canals. Additional identifiers include a mesial marginal ridge groove, a deep mesial root concavity, and a mesial cusp ridge longer than the distal; these complicate scaling and endodontic access.
Maxillary 1st Premolar ‚Äî Canal Counts
# canals123
Prevalence‚âà 9%‚âà 85%‚âà 6%
High‚Äëyield review: occlusal hexagon; long central groove with fewer supplemental grooves; buccal cusp height > palatal; no central pit (separate mesial/distal pits).

text: Which posterior tooth has its lingual height of contour in the occlusal third instead of the middle third?
explanation: In posterior teeth, the lingual height of contour is typically in the middle third; the mandibular second premolar is the exception because its prominent lingual cusp development places the lingual HOC in the occlusal third. High‚Äëyield review: 5 lobes; Y/H/U forms; relatively symmetric crown in 2‚Äëcusp types; apex close to mental foramen.

text: Which tooth has the most prominent labial ridge?
explanation: The labial ridge is exclusive to canines and is most prominent on the maxillary canine. Compare to other ridges: buccal (cusp) ridge‚Äîonly on premolars, most pronounced on the maxillary first premolar; cervical ridge‚Äîon all primary teeth and permanent molars in the cervical third buccally; marginal ridges‚Äîon all teeth (posterior occlusal borders and anterior lingual borders); oblique ridge‚Äîon maxillary molars (ML‚ÜíDB); triangular ridges‚Äîon all posterior cusps (ML cusp of maxillary molars has two); transverse ridges‚Äîwhere B and L triangular ridges meet (common on maxillary premolars and mandibular molars).

text: Which permanent teeth are least likely to be lost due to caries?
explanation: Mandibular incisors are least likely to be lost to caries because their crowns are small and smooth and benefit from tongue and saliva cleansing; they rarely have deep pits or fissures. They are more often lost for periodontal reasons or crowding, whereas maxillary first molars are early erupting and occlusally complex and thus caries‚Äëprone. High‚Äëyield review: mandibular incisors‚Äîsmallest tooth (central), most symmetrical tooth (central), incisal edge lingual to long axis; cingulum central to slightly distal and indistinct.

text: Which nerves typically innervate the roots of the maxillary first molar?
option1: All roots by the posterior superior alveolar nerve
option2: Distobuccal and palatal roots by PSA; mesiobuccal root by MSA
option3: Mesiobuccal and distobuccal roots by ASA; palatal root by nasopalatine nerve
option4: Palatal root by greater palatine nerve; buccal roots by PSA
explanation: The maxillary first molar commonly exhibits dual innervation: the distobuccal and palatal roots are supplied by the posterior superior alveolar nerve, while the mesiobuccal root is often supplied by the middle superior alveolar nerve. Because the MSA can be absent, a PSA infiltration alone may leave the MB root responsive; use supplemental infiltration over the MB root or an MSA block when present. High‚Äëyield review: three roots; oblique ridge; DL cusp small; MB root often with MB2 canal.

text: A patient fractures the lingual cusp of tooth #13 (maxillary second premolar). This most likely occurred due to contact with which cusp of which mandibular tooth during a non-working movement?
explanation: In normal intercuspation, the lingual cusps of maxillary premolars and molars are functional cusps, occluding in fossae of mandibular teeth. During excursive movements, particularly non-working (balancing) side excursions, interferences occur when functional cusps of maxillary teeth contact non-functional cusps of mandibular teeth. Here, the lingual cusp of maxillary premolar #13 fractured against the mesiobuccal cusp of mandibular first molar #19 during a right-to-left non-working movement. High-yield review: Working side = functional cusp contacts. Non-working side = interferences, destructive. Functional cusps = maxillary lingual, mandibular buccal. Clinical: Non-working interferences predispose to cusp fracture and TMJ strain.

text: Which of the following best describes a non-working (balancing) side interference during mandibular movement?
option1: Contact between lingual cusps of maxillary molars and fossae of mandibular molars on the working side
option2: Contact between buccal cusps of mandibular molars and fossae of maxillary molars on the working side
option3: Contact between non-functional cusps of maxillary and mandibular teeth on the balancing side
option4: Contact between anterior teeth during protrusion
explanation: During lateral movements, the working side is the side toward which the mandible moves, while the opposite is the non-working (balancing) side. Ideally, contacts occur only on the working side or anterior teeth. When non-functional cusps (maxillary buccal and mandibular lingual) contact on the non-working side, this is a non-working interference. Such interferences are destructive, transmitting lateral forces that can lead to cusp fracture or periodontal trauma. High-yield review: Functional cusps = maxillary lingual, mandibular buccal. Non-functional cusps = maxillary buccal, mandibular lingual. Non-working interference = destructive contact on balancing side. Goal: eliminate balancing side contacts.

text: During a left working movement, the lingual cusp of the maxillary first molar (#14) travels along which mandibular tooth surface?
explanation: In working side movements, functional cusps (maxillary lingual, mandibular buccal) move against guiding grooves and fossae. During a left working movement, the lingual cusp of maxillary first molar #14 travels along the distobuccal groove of mandibular first molar #19. This cusp-groove relationship ensures stable intercuspation and prevents interferences. High-yield review: Working side = functional cusp contacts. Maxillary lingual cusps ‚Üí grooves/fossae of mandibular molars (distobuccal groove). Mandibular buccal cusps ‚Üí fossae of maxillary molars.

text: During a protrusive mandibular movement, the mandibular posterior cusps move against which surfaces of the maxillary teeth?
option1: Posterior slopes of maxillary buccal cusps
option2: Anterior slopes of maxillary lingual cusps
explanation: In protrusion, the mandible moves forward guided by anterior teeth. Posterior teeth should disclude as mandibular posterior cusps slide against the anterior slopes of maxillary lingual cusps. This anterior guidance protects posterior teeth from destructive protrusive forces. High-yield review: Protrusion = mandibular posterior cusps contact anterior slopes of maxillary lingual cusps. Retrusion = posterior slopes of cusps. Clinical: Anterior guidance protects posterior teeth and TMJ from harmful forces.

text: Which permanent tooth is considered the most symmetrical in crown morphology?
explanation: The mandibular central incisor is the smallest and most symmetrical tooth in the permanent dentition. Its mesial and distal surfaces appear almost identical, and the mesioincisal and distoincisal angles are equally sharp. Option 1 (maxillary central) has asymmetry between mesial and distal angles. Option 3 (mandibular lateral) is slightly larger and twisted distally at the incisal edge, making it less symmetrical. Option 4 (maxillary lateral) shows variable morphology, sometimes peg-shaped, and is the least symmetrical of anterior teeth. High-yield review: Mandibular central incisor = smallest tooth, most symmetrical, first succedaneous tooth to erupt.

text: A developmental groove or fissure that may extend from the lingual surface onto the root is most often seen in which tooth?
explanation: The maxillary lateral incisor may present with a linguogingival fissure (palato-radicular groove). This developmental groove begins on the cingulum of the lingual surface and extends apically onto the root surface. It complicates scaling and root planing as it harbors plaque and calculus. Option 1 (maxillary central) does not typically exhibit this groove. Options 3 and 4 (canines) have long roots but do not characteristically display this fissure. High-yield review: Maxillary lateral incisor‚Äîvariable morphology, peg laterals possible, prone to linguogingival groove which complicates periodontal therapy.

text: Which permanent tooth may present difficulties during root planing due to a linguogingival groove extending inciso-apically from the cingulum?
explanation: The maxillary lateral incisor often exhibits a linguogingival (palato-radicular) groove that extends from the cingulum inciso-apically toward the root. This groove can be deep and difficult to instrument, making root planing challenging and increasing risk for endo-perio lesions. Options 1, 3, and 4 (central incisor, mandibular central, and mandibular canine) do not have this prominent groove and are less problematic during scaling. High-yield review: Maxillary lateral incisor‚Äîrisk of periodontal disease progression due to linguogingival groove; complicates root planing and periodontal management.

text: In the primary mandibular first molar, which cusp is the tallest and sharpest?
explanation:
The **primary mandibular first molar** is unique in its crown morphology. The **mesiolingual (ML) cusp** is the tallest and sharpest cusp, serving as a key distinguishing feature. However, the **mesiobuccal (MB) cusp** is the **largest** cusp in terms of bulk and occlusal table contribution. This asymmetry is characteristic of this tooth.

üëâ **High-yield review:**
- Primary mandibular first molar: MB cusp = largest; ML cusp = tallest/sharpest.
- Prominent cervical bulge (MB).
- Occlusal table shifted distally.

text: Which of the following best describes the root morphology of the mandibular lateral incisor?
option3: Root with distal inclination and concavities (mesial > distal)
explanation:
The **mandibular lateral incisor** is slightly larger than the mandibular central incisor, but both share similar root morphology. The root typically shows a **distal inclination** and has developmental depressions (concavities) on both mesial and distal surfaces, with the **mesial concavity deeper**. This morphology helps stabilize the tooth in the arch but can complicate endodontic treatment and scaling procedures.

üëâ **High-yield review:**
- Mandibular central/lateral incisors: longest roots among incisors.
- Cross-section: 'hourglass' shaped root due to concavities.
- Distal inclination common in mandibular laterals.

text: How does a steep condylar guidance (steep incline of condyles) affect cusp morphology?
option4: Cusps are eliminated in favor of flat occlusion
explanation: The condylar guidance is the angle formed by the path of the condyle during protrusive and lateral mandibular movements. A steep condylar guidance allows for taller, sharper cusps and deeper fossae, since there is more vertical clearance during excursions. In contrast, a shallow condylar guidance restricts cusp height, requiring cusps to be shorter and flatter to avoid occlusal interferences. Other determinants of cusp height and occlusal morphology include: Anterior guidance: Steeper anterior guidance permits taller cusps; shallow guidance requires flatter cusps. Plane of occlusion: A flatter plane allows taller cusps, whereas a steeper plane necessitates shorter cusps. Curve of Spee: A more acute curve reduces cusp height; a flatter curve allows taller cusps. Mandibular lateral translation (Bennett movement): Greater immediate lateral shift requires shorter cusps; minimal shift allows taller cusps. üëâ High-yield review: Steep condylar guidance ‚Üí Taller cusps, deeper fossae. Shallow condylar guidance ‚Üí Shorter cusps, shallower fossae. Determinants: condylar guidance, anterior guidance, occlusal plane, curve of Spee, Bennett movement.

text: In a normal Class I occlusion, the mesiobuccal cusp of the maxillary first molar occludes with which groove of the mandibular first molar?
explanation: In Angle‚Äôs Class I occlusion, the key landmark is that the mesiobuccal cusp of the maxillary first molar fits precisely into the mesiobuccal groove of the mandibular first molar. This relationship provides stable intercuspation and serves as the foundation for defining normal occlusion. Class II occurs when the maxillary first molar is mesially positioned relative to the mandibular molar, while Class III occurs when it is distally positioned. üëâ High-yield review: Class I: MB cusp of maxillary 1st molar ‚Üí MB groove of mandibular 1st molar. Class II: Max molars positioned mesially. Class III: Max molars positioned distally.

text: Which feature best describes the crown morphology of the mandibular central and lateral incisors when viewed from the incisal aspect?
option1: Wider mesiodistally than faciolingually, prominent marginal ridges, and a distal pit
option2: Wider faciolingually than mesiodistally, no prominent marginal ridges, no distal pit
option3: Equal mesiodistal and faciolingual dimensions with deep lingual fossa
explanation: The mandibular central and lateral incisors are the most symmetrical teeth in the arch. From the incisal aspect, their crowns are wider faciolingually than mesiodistally, reflecting their narrow mesiodistal dimension. Unlike maxillary incisors, they have no prominent marginal ridges, no lingual pit, and no significant fossa, giving them a relatively smooth lingual surface. This morphology contributes to reduced plaque accumulation compared to maxillary incisors. üëâ High-yield review: Mandibular incisors: wider FL than MD, minimal lingual anatomy. Maxillary incisors: wider MD than FL, with prominent marginal ridges and lingual fossa/pit. Mandibular central incisor: smallest and most symmetrical permanent tooth.

text: Which tooth is the longest in the permanent dentition?
explanation:
The **maxillary canine** is the longest tooth overall, with an average length of ~27 mm due to its exceptionally long root and crown. Its root is the longest of any permanent tooth and provides excellent anchorage, earning it the title 'cornerstone of the arch.' Canines are critical for canine guidance during lateral excursions.

üëâ Maxillary vs. Mandibular Canines (high-yield differences):
- Maxillary canine: longest tooth overall; bulkier crown; cusp tip sharper; prominent labial ridge; longer root; cingulum prominent and centered.
- Mandibular canine: crown appears longer; narrower mesiodistally; cusp tip blunter; labial ridge less pronounced; root slightly shorter; cingulum smaller and often distal.

üëâ General rules:
- Maxillary canine = longest tooth overall.
- Canines are the only teeth with a labial ridge (most prominent in the maxillary).
- Canines resist caries and extraction due to long roots and strong bone support.

text: Which permanent tooth has the longest crown?
explanation:
The **mandibular canine** has the longest crown of any permanent tooth. Its crown is taller incisogingivally compared to all others, though its root is slightly shorter than that of the maxillary canine. Because of this, the maxillary canine remains the longest tooth overall, while the mandibular canine is notable for its tall crown and functional role in occlusion.

üëâ Maxillary vs. Mandibular Canines (high-yield differences):
- Crown length: mandibular > maxillary.
- Root length: maxillary > mandibular.
- Cingulum: maxillary is prominent/central; mandibular is smaller and distal.
- Mesial outline: mandibular is straighter with the root axis; maxillary is more convex.

üëâ General rules:
- Mandibular canine = longest crown.
- Canines have the greatest combined crown + root bulk.
- Their position at the corners of the arch makes them critical for esthetics and occlusal guidance.

text: A child presents with permanent central incisors, lateral incisors, and canines showing pitting defects in the incisal one-third of the crowns. Which type of enamel defect is most consistent with this finding?
explanation:
Enamel hypoplasia is a quantitative defect where too little enamel matrix is laid down during amelogenesis. It produces permanent pits, grooves, or missing enamel. Distribution across the incisal one-third of several teeth reflects the timing of the developmental insult. Systemic illnesses (fever, malnutrition, congenital infection) cause symmetric defects; local trauma to a primary predecessor causes localized hypoplasia.

By contrast, hypomaturation leaves normal thickness enamel but poorly matured‚Äîopaque, chalky, mottled. Hypocalcified enamel is normal in thickness but poorly mineralized, soft, and chips easily. Fluorosis from excess fluoride produces diffuse mottled opacities, not focal pits.

High-yield points:
  • Hypoplasia = pitting/grooves from reduced matrix
  • Hypomaturation = chalky/mottled enamel
  • Hypocalcified = soft, friable enamel
  • Fluorosis = diffuse, symmetric mottling
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • Hypomaturation: opacity without pits
  • Hypocalcification: soft enamel, not pits
  • Fluorosis: diffuse mottling, not localized pitting

text: At what age is enamel formation completed for the permanent maxillary canine?
explanation:
Permanent maxillary canines begin calcifying around 4‚Äì5 months. Enamel formation completes at about 6‚Äì7 years. Eruption occurs later (~11‚Äì12 years maxillary, ~9‚Äì10 years mandibular), and root completion follows 2‚Äì3 years post-eruption.

High-yield points:
  • Enamel complete: 6‚Äì7 years
  • Eruption: 11‚Äì12 y (max), 9‚Äì10 y (mand)
  • Root completion: 2‚Äì3 y post-eruption
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • 2‚Äì3 years: too early (incisors)
  • 4‚Äì5 years: enamel still forming
  • 8‚Äì9 years: crown complete earlier, eruption near

text: Contour lines of Owen are found in which dental tissue, and what are they analogous to?
option2: Dentin; analogous to Striae of Retzius
option3: Cementum; analogous to incremental lines of Salter
explanation:
The contour lines of Owen are found in dentin, representing metabolic disturbances during dentinogenesis. They are analogous to the Striae of Retzius in enamel, which mark rhythmic deposition and stress events. In cementum, similar features are called incremental lines of Salter.

High-yield points:
  • Owen‚Äôs lines = dentin
  • Analogous to Striae of Retzius in enamel
  • Incremental lines of Salter = cementum
Why other options are incorrect:
  • Perikymata: enamel surface grooves
  • Salter: cementum, not dentin
  • Hunter‚ÄìSchreger bands: prism orientation in enamel

text: Which cusps are considered supporting (working, centric) cusps in normal occlusion?
option1: Buccal cusps of maxillary posterior teeth and lingual cusps of mandibular posterior teeth
option2: Lingual cusps of maxillary posterior teeth and buccal cusps of mandibular posterior teeth
option4: Incisal edges of anterior teeth only
explanation:
Supporting cusps (centric/working) include the lingual cusps of maxillary posterior teeth and buccal cusps of mandibular posterior teeth. They maintain vertical dimension and contact central fossae or marginal ridges. Non-supporting cusps (maxillary buccal, mandibular lingual) shear food and protect tissues but don‚Äôt maintain occlusal stability.

High-yield points:
  • Supporting cusps: maxillary lingual + mandibular buccal
  • Non-supporting: maxillary buccal + mandibular lingual
  • Function: vertical support, occlusal stability
Why other options are incorrect:
  • Option 1: reversed; those are non-supporting
  • Option 3: not all cusps are supporting
  • Option 4: anterior edges aren‚Äôt centric cusps

text: Which tooth is most likely to present with three cusps due to absence of the distolingual cusp?
explanation:
The maxillary second molar is the tooth most likely to exhibit variation in cusp number.

While the standard morphology includes four cusps (mesiobuccal, distobuccal, mesiolingual, and distolingual), the distolingual cusp is often reduced or absent. When missing, the tooth has only three cusps, forming a classic ‚Äúheart-shaped‚Äù molar morphology. This is distinct from the mandibular first molar, which typically has five cusps, and the maxillary first molar, which reliably has four cusps and sometimes a cusp of Carabelli.

High-yield recap: Maxillary 2nd molar may lack the distolingual cusp ‚Üí ‚Äúheart-shaped‚Äù 3-cusp molar.

text: Which ligament limits retrusion of the mandible?
explanation:
The stylomandibular ligament extends from the styloid process of the temporal bone to the angle of the mandible.

It functions to limit excessive retrusion of the mandible. In contrast, the temporomandibular ligament (lateral ligament) prevents posterior displacement of the condyle into the external auditory meatus. The sphenomandibular ligament acts as passive support, while the lateral pole attachment relates to disc anchoring rather than retrusion limitation.

High-yield recap: Stylomandibular ligament = limits retrusion. Temporomandibular ligament = prevents posterior dislocation.
